0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Rheumatoid arthritis (Moderate to Severe): (IV infusion; less than 60 kg) 500 mg IV infusion over 30 minutes; repeat doses at 2 and 4 weeks after first infusion and every 4 weeks thereafter
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (Moderate to Severe): (IV infusion; 60 to 100 kg) 750 mg IV infusion over 30 minutes; repeat doses at 2 and 4 weeks after first infusion and every 4 weeks thereafter
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (Moderate to Severe): (IV infusion; more than 100 kg) 1000 mg IV infusion over 30 minutes; repeat doses at 2 and 4 weeks after first infusion and every 4 weeks thereafter
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (Moderate to Severe): (SUBQ dosing; with IV loading dose) give weight-based IV loading dose, then 125 mg SUBQ within 1 day of loading dose, followed by 125 mg SUBQ once weekly
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (Moderate to Severe): (SUBQ dosing; without IV loading dose) 125 mg SUBQ weekly
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (Moderate to Severe): (transitioning from IV to SUBQ therapy) 125 mg SUBQ in place of next scheduled IV dose, followed by 125 mg SUBQ once weekly

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (Moderate to Severe), active, polyarticular: (6 yr or older; weighing less than 75 kg) 10 mg/kg given by IV infusion over 30 min; repeat doses at 2 and 4 weeks after first infusion and every 4 weeks thereafter
  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (Moderate to Severe), active, polyarticular: (6 yr or older; weighing 75 kg to 100 kg) 750 mg given by IV infusion over 30 min; repeat doses at 2 and 4 weeks after first infusion and every 4 weeks thereafter
  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (Moderate to Severe), active, polyarticular: (6 yr or older; weighing more than 100 kg) 1000 mg given by IV infusion over 30 min; repeat doses at 2 and 4 weeks after first infusion and every 4 weeks thereafter

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (Moderate to Severe), active, polyarticular
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (Moderate to Severe)
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
Rheumatoid arthritis, Early Disease, Methotrexate Naive with Poor Prognostic Factors

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: Specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Hepatic:
  • -- Hepatitis B reactivation has been associated with antirheumatic therapies; screen for viral hepatitis prior to initiating therapy
  • Immunologic:
  • -- Hypersensitivity reactions, including anaphylaxis or anaphylactoid reactions, have been reported; permanent discontinuation recommended
  • --Serious infections (eg, sepsis, pneumonia), including fatalities, have been reported, especially with concomitant immunosuppressant therapy; caution advised in patients with a history of recurrent infections, underlying conditions which predispose to infections, or chronic, latent, or localized infections; discontinue if a serious infection develops
  • Respiratory:
  • -- Screen for latent TB prior to initiating therapy and treat if positive
  • -- COPD; increased risk for adverse effects and disease exacerbation; monitoring recommended
  • Concomitant Use:
  • -- Concurrent use of tumor necrosis factor antagonists is not recommended
  • -- Do not give live vaccines during or within 3 months after abatacept therapy
  • -- Concurrent use of other biologic rheumatoid arthritis therapy, including anakinra, is not recommended

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea (5% or greater)
  • Immunologic:Infectious disease (37.6% to 54%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (Adult, 12.4% to 18%; pediatric, 5% or greater)
  • Respiratory:Nasopharyngitis (12% to 18%), Upper respiratory infection (10% or greater)
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Cellulitis (0.2% to 0.5%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Diverticulitis (0.2% to 0.5%)
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis (Less than 0.1%), Infectious disease, Serious (3%), Sepsis
  • Renal:Pyelonephritis, acute (0.2% to 0.5%), Urinary tract infectious disease (6%)
  • Respiratory:Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (8%), Bronchitis (5% to 13%), Pneumonia (Less than 5%)
  • Other:Cancer (1.3%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Abatacept is a cytotoxic T lymphocyte antigen immunoglobulin (CTLA-4 Ig), a fusion protein, which consists of CTLA linked to modified heavy-chain constant region of human IgG1. It is a biological response modifier that demonstrates anti-inflammatory effects by downregulating T cell activation. Abatacept binds to CD80 and CD86 receptors on the antigen-presenting cell and prevents them from binding to CD28 on the T cell for optimal T cell activation.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Total body clearance, IV, adults: 0.22 mL/hr/kg
  • Total body clearance, IV, pediatric: 0.4 mL/hr/kg
  • Total body clearance, subQ: 0.28 mL/hr/kg

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Intravenous
    • use ONLY the silicone-free disposable syringe provided with each vial; discard any solutions inadvertently reconstituted with a siliconized syringe
    • additional silicone-free disposable syringes may be obtained by contacting Bristol-Myers Squibb at 1-800-ORENCIA
    • during reconstitution to dissolve powder with 10 mL of sterile water for injection, rotate gently and DO NOT shake vial (to avoid foaming)
    • after reconstitution, vent the vial with a needle to dissipate any foam that may be present
    • concentration of the reconstituted solution is 25 mg/mL
    • further dilution to 100 mL is necessary; from a 100 mL NS infusion bag or bottle, withdraw a volume equal to the volume of reconstituted solution required for the patient's dose; slowly add the reconstituted abatacept solution from each vial into the infusion bag or bottle using the same silicone-free disposable syringe provided with each vial; gently mix
    • final concentration will depend on the amount of drug added; discard remaining solution in vials
    • administer over 30 minutes with an infusion set and a sterile, nonpyrogenic, low-protein-binding filter (pore size of 0.2 micrometer to 1.2 micrometer)
    • complete infusion within 24 hours of reconstitution; diluted infusion solution may be stored at room temperature or refrigerated at 2 degrees C to 8 degrees C (36 degrees F to 46 degrees F) before use
    • should not be infused concomitantly in the same intravenous line with other agents
  • Subcutaneous
    • single-dose prefilled syringe is only for subQ administration; not for IV infusion
    • rotate injection sites; do not give in areas where skin is tender, bruised, red, or hard

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• C-reactive protein; erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR); rheumatoid factor
  • infections (chronic, latent, or localized); patients who develop a new infection during treatment should be monitored closely
  • respiratory status should be monitored in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • signs and symptoms of anaphylaxis, anaphylactoid reaction, and hypersensitivity reactions (hypotension, urticaria, and dyspnea)
  • signs and symptoms of malignancy (drugs that inhibit T cell activation including abatacept affect the host defenses against malignancies)
  • symptom improvement (e.g., tender/swollen joints, morning stiffness, pain)
  • tuberculin skin test prior to initiating abatacept.

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Orencia
  • Intravenous Powder for Solution: 250 MG
  • Subcutaneous Solution: 125 MG/ML

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient that live vaccines should be avoided during and for 3 months after therapy.
  • Counsel diabetic patient using a GDH-PQQ based glucose test that alternative testing is needed on days they receive IV abatacept due to the maltose in the solution.
  • Drug may cause fever, nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain, headaches, nasopharyngitis, cough, or upper respiratory infections.
  • Instruct patient about increased risk of infection and to report signs/symptoms of a new infection or a recurring infection (hepatitis B, tuberculosis) during therapy.
  • Warn COPD patient that drug may exacerbate respiratory symptoms.
  • Advise patient about proper injection sites and rotation.
